title: Induced Subgraph Queries
statementHtml:
You are given an unweighted, undirected graph GG with nn nodes and mm edges. The graph GG contains no self-loops or multiple edges.

We denote the node set of GG as VV. For any node subset V′⊆VV′⊆V, the corresponding induced subgraph, denoted by G[V′]G[V′], is defined as follows:

Your task is to answer qq queries. Each query provides three integers ll, rr, and kk. Denoting V′={l,l+1,…,r}V′={l,l+1,…,r}, you need to find the kk-th smallest value among f(l,G[V′])f(l,G[V′]), f(l+1,G[V′])f(l+1,G[V′]), …… , f(r,G[V′])f(r,G[V′]) (i.e., the kk-th value in increasing order; repeated values are counted multiple times).

Here, f(u,G[V′])=⨁(u,v)∈G[V′]vf(u,G[V′])=⨁(u,v)∈G[V′]v. In other words, it is the bitwise XOR value of the labels of all adjacent nodes of node uu in graph G[V′]G[V′].

You might want to read the notes for a better understanding.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1.5⋅1041≤t≤1.5⋅104). The description of the test cases follows.

Each test case begins with two integers nn and mm (2≤n≤1.5⋅1052≤n≤1.5⋅105, 1≤m≤1.5⋅1051≤m≤1.5⋅105) — the number of nodes and edges, respectively.

The next mm lines each contain two integers uiui and vivi (1≤ui,vi≤n1≤ui,vi≤n, ui≠viui≠vi), representing an undirected edge between nodes uiui and vivi.

The next line contains a single integer qq (1≤q≤1.5⋅1051≤q≤1.5⋅105) — the number of queries.

Each of the next qq lines contains three integers ll, rr, and kk (1≤l≤r≤n1≤l≤r≤n, 1≤k≤r−l+11≤k≤r−l+1), defining a query about the induced subgraph G[{l,…,r}]G[{l,…,r}].

It is guaranteed that the graph contains no self-loops or multiple edges.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn,mm, and qq over all test cases does not exceed 1.5⋅1051.5⋅105, respectively.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output qq integers, representing the answer for each query.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, the input graph GG is the one in the following picture.

The given graph GG.

In the first query, the induced subgraph G[{1,2}]G[{1,2}] is the one in the following picture. We can see that nodes 11 and 22 have no adjacent nodes. Thus, f(1,G[{1,2}])=f(2,G[{1,2}])=0f(1,G[{1,2}])=f(2,G[{1,2}])=0. The 22-nd smallest value is 00.

G[{1,2}]G[{1,2}].

In the second query, the induced subgraph G[{1,2,3}]G[{1,2,3}] is the one in the following picture. We can see that f(1,G[{1,2,3}])=3f(1,G[{1,2,3}])=3, f(2,G[{1,2,3}])=3f(2,G[{1,2,3}])=3, and f(3,G[{1,2,3}])=1⊕2=3f(3,G[{1,2,3}])=1⊕2=3. The 11-st smallest value is 33.

G[{1,2,3}]G[{1,2,3}].

In the third query, the induced subgraph G[{2,3,4}]G[{2,3,4}] is the one in the following picture. We can see that f(2,G[{2,3,4}])=3⊕4=7f(2,G[{2,3,4}])=3⊕4=7, f(3,G[{2,3,4}])=2⊕4=6f(3,G[{2,3,4}])=2⊕4=6, and f(4,G[{2,3,4}])=2⊕3=1f(4,G[{2,3,4}])=2⊕3=1. The 33-rd smallest value is 77.

G[{2,3,4}]G[{2,3,4}].
